name: Blue Ridge Tunnel
description: Walk the restored 1850s Blue Ridge Railroad tunnel on a 2.25-mile crushed-gravel path with dramatic stone portals linking Afton and the Rockfish Valley.
detailedDescription: The Blue Ridge Tunnel, engineered by Claudius Crozet in the 1850s beneath Rockfish Gap, now lets hikers and cyclists travel nearly a mile through the historic rail bore between Skyline Drive and the Blue Ridge Parkway.
image1Desc: Cyclist with headlight in dark tunnel, wet rocky walls.

name: Brimstone Trail
description: Steep 0.8-mile red-blazed climb skirting rocky cliffs with sweeping Three Ridges views, laurel thickets, and fern-covered “rock gardens.”
detailedDescription: Brimstone Trail tackles 0.8 miles of rocky cliffs beneath Wintergreen’s Plunge, mixing steep ups and downs, laurel thickets, and sweeping views toward Three Ridges—best tackled with care during icy months.
image1Desc: Rocky trail with hiker in distance, green leaves in foreground.
image2Desc: Wooden sign with red and yellow text, directions to trails, gravel road background.

name: Cedar Ciffs North Trail
description: Cool, damp 0.7-mile north-facing spur paralleling Cedar Cliffs with mossy boulders, ferny slopes, and connections to the primary overlook trail.
detailedDescription: Cedar Cliffs North Trail parallels the main Cedar Cliffs route on a cool, boulder-strewn north slope, offering 0.7 miles of mossy rock gardens and damp microclimates before connecting back to the overlook (closed in winter).
image1Desc: Wooden trail sign with colored text and arrow, rocky background, and greenery.

name: Chestnut Springs Trail
description: 1.1-mile yellow-red loop leaving Shamokin Gorge to traverse oak-hickory ridges, spring wildflowers, and stream crossings near Wintergreen.
detailedDescription: Chestnut Springs Trail runs 1.1 miles from rhododendron-lined Shamokin Gorge to sunny oak-hickory slopes, revealing spring wildflowers like bloodroot and wild ginger—long pants recommended to avoid stinging nettle.
image1Desc: Wooden trail sign with engraved text surrounded by lush green foliage.

name: Crabtree Falls
description: Crabtree Falls features five major cascades dropping 1,200 feet—the highest vertical-drop waterfall east of the Mississippi—with paved lower overlook and a 3-mile trail to upper vistas.
detailedDescription: Crabtree Falls cascades 1,200 vertical feet across five major drops, with an accessible first overlook near the parking area and a 3-mile trail to additional viewpoints for hikers seeking panoramic Blue Ridge vistas.
image1Desc: Waterfall cascading over rocks surrounded by lush green foliage.

name: Devils Knob Trail
description: 0.6-mile stroll from the Blue Ridge Overlook across catoctin greenstone ledges with rock “gardens,” birding, and views toward Pond Hollow.
detailedDescription: Devils Knob Trail begins at the Blue Ridge Overlook and winds 0.6 miles past catoctin greenstone outcrops blanketed in spring saxifrage, delivering birdwatching and sweeping views toward Pond Hollow and Fortunes Ridge.
image1Desc: Rocky forest trail with scattered sunlight filtering through green foliage.

name: Fortune’s Cove Nature Preserve
description: Strenuous 5.3-mile loop managed by The Nature Conservancy climbing 1,500 feet through rocky glades and intact forest to panoramic cove overlooks.
detailedDescription: Fortune’s Cove Nature Preserve challenges hikers with a 5.3-mile loop that gains 1,500 feet before rewarding them with rocky glade vistas, rare plant communities, and a shorter lower loop option for quicker outings.
image1Desc: Trail sign on curved tree, surrounded by dense green forest.

name: Fortune’s Ridge Trail
description: 1.1-mile red-blazed path following Fortunes Ridge stream with cascades, laurel blooms, and access points from Fortunes Ridge and Wintergreen Drive.
detailedDescription: Fortune’s Ridge Trail follows a cold mountain stream over cascades and a small waterfall, with laurel thickets blooming pink each June and multiple access points from Fortunes Ridge Drive or Brimstone Trail.
image1Desc: Wooden trail sign reads "Laurel Ridge Loop 3 Mile" in forest.

name: Hemlock Springs Loop
description: 0.8-mile yellow-red loop highlighting pink and yellow lady’s-slipper habitat, old-growth hemlock remnants, and moderate climbs near Wintergreen.
detailedDescription: Hemlock Springs Loop is a 0.8-mile route known for pink and yellow lady’s slippers and an old-growth hemlock stand impacted by woolly adelgid—offering a sensitive habitat best navigated with care.
image1Desc: Person standing on large rock surrounded by green grass.

name: Highlands Leisure Trail
description: Half-mile connector between Blackrock Village and the Wintergarden with short climbs, older-growth forest, and an overlook of Highlands ski slopes.
detailedDescription: Highlands Leisure Trail connects Wintergreen’s Blackrock Village to the Wintergarden via a 0.5-mile yellow-blazed path that dips through older-growth forest and includes an overlook of the Highlands ski slopes.
image1Desc: Wooded trail with steps surrounded by lush green foliage and sunlight.

name: Humpback Rocks
description: Popular 2-mile loop to the Humpback Rocks summit, ascending 740 feet for 360° Blue Ridge views near Parkway milepost 5.8.
detailedDescription: Humpback Rocks rewards a short but steep 2-mile loop climb with 360-degree Blue Ridge panoramas; start from the visitor center near Parkway milepost 5.8 and plan on about 45 minutes up, 20 down.
image1Desc: Sunrise over misty valley with rocky foreground and scattered clouds.
address: Humpback Gap Parking Area, Milepost 5.8 Blue Ridge Parkway, Lyndhurst, VA 22952

name: James River State Park
description: State park along the James River with 15+ miles of multiuse trails, riverfront overlooks, boat launches, cabins, and full-service canoe livery.
detailedDescription: James River State Park spans 1,500 acres with 15 miles of multi-use trails, three miles of river frontage, boat launches, cabins, campsites, and a seasonal canoe livery delivering sweeping views of the James and Norwood across the water.
image1Desc: Stone entrance sign reading "James River Wildlife Management Area" among trees.

name: Kids in Parks: Virginia Blue Ridge Railway Trail
description: Family-friendly TRACK Trail at Piney River Depot with self-guided nature activities, flat rail-trail mileage, and prizes through Kids in Parks.
detailedDescription: The Kids in Parks TRACK Trail on the Virginia Blue Ridge Railway Trail turns a family bike or hike into an educational scavenger hunt with self-guided brochures, prizes for logged adventures, and easy access from the Piney River depot.
image1Desc: Wooden covered bridge over forest path; red bicycle leaning nearby.
address: 3124 Patrick Henry Highway, Piney River, VA 22964

name: Laurel Ridge Loop
description: 1.6-mile yellow loop sampling mountain laurel, birch, and oak-hickory forest with rocky footing and parking at Wintergreen’s Lot F.
detailedDescription: Laurel Ridge Loop covers 1.6 miles of moderate terrain over laurel thickets, yellow birch, and rocky sections, eventually circling back to Wintergreen’s Parking Lot F for an accessible forest sampler.
image1Desc: Wooden trail sign with yellow and red text in forest setting.

name: Lower Shamokin Falls Trail
description: 1.7-mile blue-blazed trek ending at Lower Shamokin Falls, weaving through dense forest after a jeep-road approach from Old Stoney Creek Road.
detailedDescription: Lower Shamokin Falls Trail meanders 1.7 miles through dense forest to the base of a cascading waterfall below Upper Shamokin Falls, beginning on a jeep road at the end of Old Stoney Creek Road.
image1Desc: Trail sign on tree reads "Lower Shamokin Falls Trail" in lush forest.

name: Mau-Har Trail
description: Three-mile Mau-Har connector through the Three Ridges Wilderness linking with the Appalachian Trail past cascades, rock scrambles, and shelters.
detailedDescription: The blue-blazed Mau-Har Trail links with the Appalachian Trail to form the famed Three Ridges loop, adding waterfalls, campsites, and rugged terrain that backpackers consider one of Virginia’s best circuits.
image1Desc: Small waterfall cascading over rocks surrounded by autumn foliage.
address: Blue Ridge Parkway Milepost 13.7, Roseland, VA 22967

name: Montebello Nature Trail
description: Half-mile nature walk beside Montebello’s former fish hatchery stream with fern-lined banks, benches, and steady bird activity.
detailedDescription: Montebello Nature Trail is a half-mile stroll along a former fish hatchery stream lined with ferns, wildflowers, and benches where you can spot dragonflies or listen for Louisiana waterthrush near Route 56.
image1Desc: People walking on a sunny forest trail surrounded by green trees.

name: Nelson County Wilderness Area
description: Protected wilderness spanning The Priest and Three Ridges with rugged Appalachian Trail miles, dramatic elevation changes, and backcountry solitude.
detailedDescription: Nelson County Wilderness Area protects nearly 10,000 rugged acres split between The Priest and Three Ridges, where the Appalachian Trail climbs from 1,000-foot river valleys to 4,000-foot summits. Backpackers find permanently protected forests, sweeping overlooks, and the wildest terrain in the Blue Ridge.
image1Desc: Hiker with a green backpack walking through a forest.
address: George Washington National Forest, Montebello, VA 24464

name: North Fork of the Piney River
description: Scenic drive and short riverside stroll showcasing Piney River cascades, stocked fishing holes, and swimming spots in Nelson County.
detailedDescription: The North Fork of the Piney River scenic drive hugs cascading water, stocked pools, and roadside pull-offs where you can cast, swim, or snap photos of the tumbling mountain stream. Follow Route 666 past Dickie Brothers Orchard and into George Washington National Forest for shady picnics beside the river.
image1Desc: Water cascading over mossy rocks surrounded by green leaves.

name: Old Appalachian Trail
description: 3.3-mile former Appalachian Trail alignment with greenstone ledges, Shenandoah Valley overlooks, and spring wildflowers across multiple access points.
detailedDescription: Once part of the official Appalachian Trail, the 3.3-mile Old Appalachian Trail winds past greenstone ledges, wildflower-filled slopes, and connectors to today’s AT near Laurel Springs Drive. Moderate-to-difficult grades reward hikers with Shenandoah Valley vistas and quiet, historic tread.
image1Desc: Narrow dirt path with yellow moss, surrounded by trees in a forest.

name: Paul’s Creek Trail
description: 0.6-mile blue-blazed valley hike culminating at Paul’s Creek waterfalls with smooth rock slabs and family-friendly cascades near Wintergreen.
detailedDescription: Paul’s Creek Trail is a 0.6-mile blue-blazed family favorite that follows a lush valley to smooth rock chutes and a series of cascading waterfalls near Crawford’s Knob. Pack water shoes and a camera—the polished boulders and cool pools are irresistible on summer days.
image1Desc: Forest stream flowing over rocks surrounded by trees and autumn leaves.

name: Pedlars Edge Trail
description: 1.6-mile difficult red trail paralleling Blackrock with pedlar formation geology, open powerline birding, and wildflower-rich edge habitat.
detailedDescription: Pedlars Edge Trail climbs 1.6 red-blazed miles through the ancient pedlar rock formation, linking to Blackrock Trail and a power-line corridor prized by birders. Expect steep, exposed sections, wildflowers, and big-sky views—plus challenging footing when winter ice settles in.
image1Desc: Bird perched on icy branch, blue sky background.

name: Pond Hollow Trail
description: One-mile red-blazed route along a geologic fault line with displaced boulders, varied plant communities, and bobcat-friendly habitat.
detailedDescription: Pond Hollow Trail is a demanding 1-mile route threaded through a geologic fault line littered with house-sized boulders and prime bobcat habitat. The red-blazed path’s maze of displaced rock and steep pitches make it one of Wintergreen’s most intriguing adventures.
image1Desc: Group of people walking through lush green forest near rocky cliff.

name: Ravens Roost Park
description: 0.5-mile yellow loop through mixed forest with wildflower displays, solitude, and access from White Oak Drive or Wintergreen Drive.
detailedDescription: Ravens Roost Park offers a half-mile yellow-blazed wander through deep forest to a favorite Skyline Drive overlook for sunrise, sunset, and wildflower spotting. Birdwatchers love the solitude, and hikers can link to White Oak Trail for a longer loop.
image1Desc: Wooden deck overlooks vast green forest landscape and distant horizon.

name: Shamokin Springs Nature Preserve
description: 0.3-mile preserve loop protecting high-elevation wetlands with braided streams, northern plant species, and easy access for families.
detailedDescription: Shamokin Springs Nature Preserve protects a rare high-elevation wetland in the middle of Wintergreen, where braided streams nurture northern plant species on an easy 0.3-mile loop. Pick up a Nature Preserve Guide at Trillium House to learn about the ferns, mosses, and wildlife thriving here.
image1Desc: Small waterfall cascading over rocks in a forest stream.
image2Desc: Mountain landscape with distant green hills and scattered clouds beneath blue sky.

name: The Plunge
description: Short yellow access spur to Blackrock featuring steep pedlar gneiss formations, panoramic overlooks, and a signature family photo spot.
detailedDescription: The Plunge is a short, steep 0.2-mile connector to Blackrock Trail that packs in pedlar gneiss rock formations, dramatic overlooks, and prime family photo spots. Take your time on the rocky steps—especially in winter—then soak up the sweeping views from both trailheads.
image1Desc: Rocky viewpoint overlooking lush, green mountains under clear blue sky.

name: Trillium Field
description: Easy 0.1-mile stroll where thousands of trillium bloom each May along Wintergreen Drive and Devils Knob Loop, with wildflowers through summer.
detailedDescription: Trillium Field is a pocket-sized 0.1-mile stroll where thousands of white and pink trillium bloom in early May on the corner of Wintergreen Drive and Devils Knob Loop. Return throughout summer to spot successive waves of wildflowers dotting the forest floor.
image1Desc: Pink and white flowers with green leaves in a forest setting.

name: Upper Shamokin Falls Trail
description: 0.4-mile yellow trail to Upper Shamokin Falls with evergreen ferns, wildflowers, and camera-ready cascades near Wintergreen.
detailedDescription: Upper Shamokin Falls Trail is a gentle 0.4-mile walk that follows the sound of tumbling water to fern-draped cascades—perfect for all ages. Stay on the marked path and off the slick rock edges, but don’t forget the camera for this signature Wintergreen scene.
image1Desc: Waterfall cascading over moss-covered rocks, surrounded by lush green forest.

name: Upper Shamokin Gorge Trail
description: Challenging 0.8-mile red trail in the Upper Shamokin Gorge with stream crossings, lush understory, and links to the Appalachian Trail.
detailedDescription: Upper Shamokin Gorge Trail challenges hikers with 0.8 rugged miles along the headwaters of Stoney Creek, including rock-hopping stream crossings and lush plant life. The red-blazed path ties into the modern Appalachian Trail plus Laurel Springs Gap overlooks for expanded loops.
image1Desc: Flowing stream through forest with rocks and autumn foliage.

name: White Oak Trail
description: 0.5-mile moderate yellow trail offering bird-friendly woods, wildflowers, and a quiet loop accessible from White Oak or Wintergreen drives.
detailedDescription: White Oak Trail serves up a half-mile of shady solitude, spring wildflowers, and birdwatching between White Oak Drive and Wintergreen Drive. Its moderate grade and dense forest make it a quick nature break any time of year.
image1Desc: Trail sign surrounded by lush green foliage in misty forest.

name: White Rock Falls
description: 2.5-mile moderate waterfall hike with natural wading pools, gorge views, and options to extend via the Slacks Overlook loop on the Parkway.
detailedDescription: White Rock Falls is a 2.5-mile moderate hike along the Blue Ridge Parkway that showcases an impressive gorge, a wading-friendly waterfall, and northeast-facing mountain views on the climb out. Combine it with the Slacks Overlook Trail for a rewarding 5-mile loop.
image1Desc: Small waterfall flowing down rocky terrain surrounded by trees.
address: Blue Ridge Parkway Milepost 19, Montebello, VA 24464

name: Three Ridges
description: Difficult 13.3-mile Three Ridges loop combining the Appalachian Trail and Mau-Har for waterfalls, rugged ridgelines, and overnight backcountry camping.
detailedDescription: The 13.3-mile Three Ridges loop is one of Virginia’s premier backpacking routes, delivering waterfalls, rocky knife-edge climbs, and big Appalachian vistas south of Wintergreen. Expect strenuous terrain, overnight camping zones, and bragging rights after tackling this rugged circuit.
image1Desc: Small waterfall flowing over rocks, surrounded by autumn leaves and trees.
address: Reeds Gap Trailhead, Route 664, Roseland, VA 22967

name: Stoney Creek Park
description: Community linear park in Stoney Creek with creekside walking path, new picnic areas, benches, and easy terrain for families.
detailedDescription: Stoney Creek Park threads an easy 0.3-mile yellow-blazed path along a restored stream corridor lined with benches, picnic tables, and new trailhead parking off Stoney Creek West. Families stroll shaded loops, dip toes in the creek, and enjoy the 2022 park expansion.
image1Desc: White flowers blooming among lush green leaves in a forest setting.
address: Stoney Creek West Drive, Nellysford, VA 22958

name: Spy Rock
description: Alternative 6.5-mile round-trip route to Spy Rock via Meadows Lane featuring sustained climbs, rocky scrambles, and sweeping summit panoramas.
detailedDescription: Spy Rock’s soaring granite dome remains open via a 6.5-mile round-trip hike from Meadows Lane (SR 826) after the fish hatchery lot closure. The route delivers 360° views over the Blue Ridge—just be prepared for limited blazes and a longer climb.
image1Desc: Hikers standing on rocky summit under cloudy blue sky, overlooking green mountains.

name: Spruce Creek Park
description: Spruce Creek Park trail hub in Nellysford connecting multiple Rockfish Valley Foundation paths, native plant gardens, and the Natural History Center.
detailedDescription: Spruce Creek Park anchors the Rockfish Valley Loop Trail system at Route 151, offering sunrise-to-sunset access to TRACK trails, a native plant garden, butterfly walk, geology trail, and the Rockfish Valley Foundation Natural History Center.
image1Desc: Tall green thistles with spiky leaves against dense forest backdrop.

name: Rockfish Valley Loop Trails
description: Flat four-mile network skirting the Rockfish River and Reid’s Creek with birding hotspots, interpretive signage, and farm-country views.
detailedDescription: Rockfish Valley Loop Trails span about four flat miles of mowed paths that trace the Rockfish River and Reid’s Creek, blend history with birding, and frame constant Blue Ridge views. Park at Spruce Creek to explore multiple trail spurs sunrise to sunset.
image1Desc: Wooden footbridge crossing over rocky ground, surrounded by lush green trees.
address: Rockfish Valley Loop Trailhead, 1368 Rockfish Valley Highway, Nellysford, VA 22958

name: Blue Ridge Parkway Loops
description: Scenic 22- or 40-mile Blue Ridge Parkway cycling loop starting near Love, Virginia, with sweeping Shenandoah Valley overlooks, Parkway climbs, and Route 76 tie-ins.
detailedDescription: Blue Ridge Parkway Loops highlight curated bike rides like the 22-mile Royal Oaks out-and-back, sending cyclists past overlooks, Route 250’s long descent, and historic stops such as the former Cookie Lady’s home in Afton.
image1Desc: Sun setting over mountains with road and railing in foreground.
address: Milepost 16, Blue Ridge Parkway, Love, VA 22952

name: Oak Ridge Loop
description: 29-mile Oak Ridge cycling loop rolling through Route 56 and Rockfish Valley backroads with historic estate views and low-traffic farm lanes.
detailedDescription: The 29-mile Oak Ridge Loop mixes Route 56 farmland, country stores, and stretches along Route 29, rewarding cyclists with rolling hills and scenic estate views before returning to the Oak Ridge parking area.
image1Desc: Stone cottage with green roof surrounded by trees and iron fence.
image2Desc: Old wooden mill with waterwheel by pond, surrounded by lush green trees.

name: Woodson's Mill Loop
description: 24-mile Woodson’s Mill ride beginning at the historic gristmill in Lowesville and circling through Massies Mill and Route 680 countryside.
detailedDescription: Woodson’s Mill Loop is a 24-mile ride beginning at the historic water-powered mill in Lowesville, linking quiet backroads, Nelson 151, Massies Mill, and orchards before returning to the restored 1790s landmark.
image1Desc: Old wooden watermill surrounded by lush greenery, near a tranquil pond.

name: Walton's Mountain Museum Loop
description: 31-mile Schuyler countryside loop from Walton’s Mountain Museum past the James River and Esmont farms with plenty of quiet ridge lines.
detailedDescription: Walton’s Mountain Museum Loop covers 31 miles of rural pavement from Schuyler past river overlooks, Esmont farm country, and back to the museum celebrating Earl Hamner Jr.’s famous TV family—perfect for heritage-minded cyclists.
image1Desc: Red brick building with American flag, labeled Schuyler Elementary School.

name: Virginia Blue Ridge Railway Trail
description: 7-mile crushed-stone rail trail along the Piney and Tye rivers with dual trailheads, equestrian access, and seasonal wildflowers.
detailedDescription: The Virginia Blue Ridge Railway Trail follows seven crushed-stone miles along the Piney and Tye rivers for hiking, biking, and horseback riding, with trailheads at Piney River Depot and Roses Mill plus restrooms, wildflowers, and abundant wildlife.
image1Desc: Trailhead sign and small building surrounded by trees under clear blue sky.
address: 3124 Patrick Henry Highway, Piney River, VA 22964

name: Nelson Scenic Loop
description: 50-mile Nelson Scenic Loop combining Route 151, Route 664, the Blue Ridge Parkway, and Route 56 for mountain vistas, orchards, and craft beverages.
detailedDescription: The Nelson Scenic Loop strings together Routes 151, 664, the Blue Ridge Parkway, and 56 into a 50-mile auto or bike tour showcasing orchards, craft beverage stops, waterfalls, and mountaintop vistas from Piedmont foothills to ridge-top summits.
image1Desc: Black butterfly on pale purple flowers with green leaves.

name: Tye River
description: 34-mile Blue Ridge stream offering Class I–II+ whitewater, mountain views, and seasonal paddling windows for experienced canoeists.
detailedDescription: The Tye River tumbles 34 miles from the Blue Ridge, serving up Class I–II+ whitewater, swimming holes, stocked trout runs, and stunning pastoral scenery—beloved by paddlers from the North and South Fork confluence to its James River meeting point.
image1Desc: Bridge over river surrounded by lush forest and distant hills.
address: Tye River Main Access 2724 Patrick Henry Highway Piney River VA 22964

name: James River
description: James River corridor on Nelson’s southeastern edge with multiple ramps, float trips, and access to the 64-mile Upper James River Water Trail.
detailedDescription: The James River forms Nelson County’s southeastern border, offering endless canoe and kayak launches, johnboat access, and fishing for smallmouth, largemouth, catfish, and sunfish along Virginia’s most storied waterway.
image1Desc: Serene river surrounded by lush green trees and distant mountains under clear sky.

name: Rockfish River
description: Rockfish River paddling routes tracing the confluence of its forks with gentle Class I–II water, winter flows, and Route 6 takeouts.
detailedDescription: The Rockfish River begins where its North and South forks meet in Nelson County, then slides southeast toward the James—providing scenic paddles, Class I riffles, and seasonal floats between Route 600, Route 6, and Scottsville.
image1Desc: Person kayaking with a dog in green kayak on a river.
address: Rockfish River Access 5156 Rockfish Valley Highway Afton VA 22920

name: Lake Nelson
description: 40-acre DGIF lake with boat ramp, year-round bank fishing, electric-motor boating, and seasonal restrooms near Arrington.
detailedDescription: Lake Nelson is a 40-acre DGIF reservoir with a concrete boat ramp, 24/7 access, and electric-motor-only fishing for largemouth bass, crappie, channel cats, and sunfish just outside Arrington.
image1Desc: Calm lake reflecting cloudy sky, surrounded by dense forest, distant mountains visible.

name: Fishing the Tye River
description: Tye River fishery stocked with trout and home to smallmouth bass, offering roadside access along Route 56 and scenic Blue Ridge runs.
detailedDescription: Fishing the Tye River rewards anglers with smallmouth bass, bluegill, and stocked trout (October–May) along the 35-mile tributary fed by the Piney and Buffalo rivers—bring waders for fly fishing runs and check DWR trout schedules.
image1Desc: Person holding brown trout over water surface, visible scales and spots.

name: Fishing the James River
description: James River angling stretches near Wingina with prime smallmouth runs, catfish hotspots, and ramps at Midway, Wingina, and the state park.
detailedDescription: Fishing the James River means chasing smallmouth bass, flathead and channel catfish, and panfish from Botetourt County through Nelson’s border, with both mountain and Piedmont stretches producing year-round action.
image1Desc: Hand holding largemouth bass with lake and trees in background.
address: Midway Boat Ramp, 106 Midway Lane, Wingina, VA 24599

name: Fishing the Little Piney River
description: Little Piney River access near Lowesville with bass and bluegill, plus proximity to Woodson’s Mill and scenic Route 666 backroads.
detailedDescription: The Little Piney River near Lowesville hides bass and bluegill at the junction of Routes 666 and 778; verify access and licenses with DWR before casting into this quiet mountain stream.
image1Desc: Silhouette of person fishing against a sky backdrop with tall trees.
amenities: Scenic Views; Parking; Water Sports; Fishing

name: Fishing the South Rockfish River
description: South Fork Rockfish River stocked trout waters with Route 6 put-in, Rt. 29 take-out, and fall-through-spring fishing windows.
detailedDescription: The South Rockfish River is stocked with catchable trout from October through May—put in near Route 6 and take out at the Route 29 wayside, and be sure to carry both Virginia fishing and trout licenses in season.
image1Desc: Hand holding fish in net with water and leaves.
address: Rockfish River Wayside, 6759 Rockfish Valley Highway, Afton, VA 22920

name: Fishing at Montebello
description: Fee-based Montebello trout ponds with gear rentals, country store, and family-friendly catch-and-keep fishing at the base of Crabtree Falls.
detailedDescription: Montebello Camping & Fishing sells passes, bait, and kids’ poles for fee-based rainbow trout ponds, giving families an easy, license-free way to reel in dinner beside Crabtree Falls Highway.
image1Desc: People fishing by a small pond, surrounded by green trees and hills.
amenities: Retail; Family Friendly; Water Sports; Fishing

name: Fishing at Lake Monocan Park
description: 20-acre Lake Monocan at Wintergreen with seasonal public access, rentals, beach amenities, and stocked fishing opportunities.
detailedDescription: Lake Monocan Park pairs a 20-acre lake with canoe, kayak, and paddleboat rentals, fishing gear, beach loungers, and grills; it’s open Memorial Day–Labor Day with public access Sunday, Monday, and Wednesday–Friday (resort guests every day).
image1Desc: Aerial view of a lush green forest, lake, and rolling hills.
address: Lake Monocan Park, 239 Monocan Drive, Nellysford, VA 22958
amenities: Boating; Picnic Area; Seasonal Menu; Water Sports; Fishing

name: Fishing at Lake Nelson
description: State-managed 40-acre lake offering largemouth, catfish, and crappie with 24-hour shoreline access and electric-only boating.
detailedDescription: Lake Nelson’s fishing access includes a boat ramp, parking, and portable toilets (March–September), with electric-motor boating and catches ranging from largemouth bass to redear sunfish in this 40-acre impoundment.
image1Desc: Person holding live fish by the mouth over blurred outdoor background.

name: Wintergreen Resort Fishing
description: Wintergreen Resort’s Orvis-endorsed fly fishing school offering classes at Lake Monocan, guided trout trips, and James River floats.
detailedDescription: Wintergreen Resort’s Orvis-endorsed fly-fishing program teaches casting on Lake Monocan, then guides guests to trout-filled mountain streams or smallmouth-rich James River floats—ideal for both first-timers and seasoned anglers.
image1Desc: Two men fishing by a river, one pointing ahead, surrounded by greenery.
address: Wintergreen Resort Outdoor Programs, 39 Mountain Inn Loop, Wintergreen, VA 22967

name: Devils Knob Golf Course
description: Elevation 3,800-foot Devils Knob Golf Course—Virginia’s highest—featuring Ellis Maples design, narrow mountain fairways, and panoramic vistas.
detailedDescription: Devils Knob Golf Course sits 3,800 feet high, making it Virginia’s coolest summer round; Ellis Maples carved narrow fairways, fast greens, and jaw-dropping Blue Ridge vistas into this 18-hole mountain test.
image1Desc: Green golf course bordered by autumn-colored trees under clear blue sky.

name: Stoney Creek Golf Course
description: Rees Jones-designed 27-hole Stoney Creek Golf Course in the Rockfish Valley mixing meandering streams, wetlands, and year-round play.
detailedDescription: Stoney Creek Golf Course is Rees Jones’ 27-hole design in the Rockfish River valley, playable year-round amid meandering streams, wetlands, and wildlife—so you can ski Wintergreen in the morning and chase birdies that afternoon.
image1Desc: Lush green golf course with autumn trees, mountain backdrop under cloudy sky.

name: Soaring
description: Guided ridge-soaring experiences over the Blue Ridge Mountains with Appalachian Soaring at Eagle’s Nest Airport in Lovingston.
detailedDescription: Shenandoah Valley Soaring operates from a gliderport in Nellysford, inviting visitors to watch—or join—weekend flights over the Blue Ridge with a 50-member club that flies classic and modern sailplanes.
image1Desc: Two aircraft on grassy field with mountains and cloudy sky background.

name: Skiing & Snowboarding
description: Wintergreen Resort’s 129 acres of skiable terrain featuring 26 slopes, terrain parks, and the state’s largest tubing hill with full rentals.
detailedDescription: Wintergreen Resort headlines Nelson County’s skiing and snowboarding with the Mid-Atlantic’s longest beginner-to-expert terrain, Virginia’s largest tubing park, five lifts (including twin six-packs), and award-winning snowsports schools.
image1Desc: Two snowboarders in winter gear, smiling, holding snowboards, with mountain background.
amenities: Water Sports; Snow Sports; Scenic Views

name: Tennis
description: Wintergreen Tennis programs spanning 19 outdoor clay and three indoor DecoTurf courts with year-round clinics for families and teams.
detailedDescription: Tennis lovers can reserve Wintergreen Resort’s 19 outdoor clay and three indoor courts—ranked among Tennis Magazine’s top 50 programs—or volley on the public courts at Nelson County High School when not in use for school events.
image1Desc: Tennis courts surrounded by trees, adjacent to green golf course, mountains in background.
address: Wintergreen Tennis Center, 581 Wintergreen Drive, Wintergreen, VA 22967

name: Swimming
description: Indoor and outdoor swimming across Wintergreen Resort, including year-round Aquatics Center pools and Lake Monocan’s summer beach.
detailedDescription: Nelson County swimming spans Wintergreen’s indoor/outdoor pools, Lake Monocan’s guarded beach (public access most days, fee for non-guests), and river dips in the James, Tye, and Rockfish for those seeking natural swimming holes.
image1Desc: Indoor pool, surrounded by potted plants and lounge seating inside a spacious room.
address: Wintergreen Aquatics & Fitness Center, 39 Mountain Inn Loop, Wintergreen, VA 22967
amenities: Pool; Outdoor Seating; Seasonal Menu; Resort

name: Afton Mountain Vineyards
description: One of Virginia’s pioneer farm wineries with vines dating to 1978, crafting estate-grown vinifera on the sunrise side of Afton Mountain. Breezy patio tastings showcase small-lot bottlings framed by Blue Ridge views.
detailedDescription: Afton Mountain Vineyards, one of Virginia’s earliest farm wineries, grows 11 grape varieties on 26 acres at 1,000 feet, producing estate wines cooled by ridge breezes and poured in a sunrise-side tasting room.
image1Desc: Rows of vines in vineyard with mountains and buildings in background.
